preparation_steps: Test soil pH to 6.0-7.0 using digital meter 2-3 weeks before planting
Work 2-3 inches compost into top 8 inches soil when temperature reaches 50°F
Choose location with partial shade receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily
planting_steps: Start Spinach seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before 2025-05-10 at 70-75°F soil temperature
Sow seeds 0.5 inches deep with 4 inch spacing between plants
Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-05-10 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F
care_instructions: Water Spinach deeply 1-1.5 inches per week checking soil moisture 2 inches deep every 3 days
Apply 10-10-10 fertilizer at 2 tablespoons per plant every 3 weeks starting 2 weeks after transplant
Mulch with 2-3 inches organic matter keeping 6 inches away from plant stem
pest_management: Inspect Spinach weekly for common zone 4a-6a pests from May through September
Apply neem oil spray at 2 tablespoons per gallon water every 14 days if pests detected
Use floating row covers first 3 weeks after transplant to prevent early season pest damage
harvest_instructions: Begin harvesting Spinach approximately 40 days after transplant when fruits reach full size
Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh Spinach at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

Choose location with full sun receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily

Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh Green Beans at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

preparation_steps: Test soil pH to 6.0-6.8 using digital meter 2-3 weeks before planting
Work 2-3 inches compost into top 8 inches soil when temperature reaches 50°F
Choose location with full sun receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily
planting_steps: Start Tomato seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before 2025-05-10 at 70-75°F soil temperature
Sow seeds 0.25 inches deep with 24 inch spacing between plants
Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-05-10 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F
care_instructions: Water Tomato deeply 1-1.5 inches per week checking soil moisture 2 inches deep every 3 days
Apply 10-10-10 fertilizer at 2 tablespoons per plant every 3 weeks starting 2 weeks after transplant
Mulch with 2-3 inches organic matter keeping 6 inches away from plant stem
pest_management: Inspect Tomato weekly for common zone 4a-6a pests from May through September
Apply neem oil spray at 2 tablespoons per gallon water every 14 days if pests detected
Use floating row covers first 3 weeks after transplant to prevent early season pest damage
harvest_instructions: Begin harvesting Tomato approximately 75 days after transplant when fruits reach full size
Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh Tomato at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

plant_groupings.spacing_notes: Plant Spinach and Green Beans in alternating rows, about 4 inches apart
Plant Tomatoes in a single row, spaced 24 inches apart, with support for indeterminate varieties

general_tips: Start seedlings indoors 4-6 weeks before the last frost date to give them a head start on the growing season.
Choose varieties of Spinach that are resistant to bolting (going to seed) such as 'Space' or 'Tyee', which can tolerate the cooler temperatures in Moncton's climate.
For Green Beans, plant bush beans instead of pole beans since they require less support and can thrive in Moncton's shorter growing season.
Select a variety of Tomato that is resistant to late blight such as 'Early Girl' or 'Patio', which can mature quickly enough to avoid the risk of disease in Moncton's cool summers.
Make sure to harden off seedlings before transplanting them outdoors by gradually exposing them to outdoor conditions over the course of 7-10 days.
Use raised beds and a good quality potting mix to improve drainage and soil structure, which can help mitigate the effects of Moncton's cold and wet climate.
Keep an eye out for common pests such as aphids, slugs, and snails, and take action promptly if you notice any damage to your plants.
